title: Biogen Stock Could Have Run Up Too Far on Alzheimer’s Drug Revival
text:
Text size

Biogen triggered a rally in its shares Tuesday morning with news of the revival of its failed Alzheimer’s drug aducanumab, but the early-morning run-up may be overdone.

Shares of Biogen (ticker: BIIB) were up as high as 37% in early trading after the biotech company seemingly erased its signal failure of the year—one that has weighed not just on Biogen, but on the entire sector. The company said that despite canceling a Phase 3 trial in March when it appeared that the drug wasn’t working, it now plans to submit aducanumab for Food and Drug Administration approval early next year.

Yet in a flurry of notes on Tuesday, shocked analysts warned that aducanumab was far from a sure thing, and noted that the benefits of the drug seemed to be slight.

In recent trading, the surge had moderated somewhat, with the stock up 26.4% on the day, still far outpacing the S&P 500’s 2.5% gain.

“At first pass the results still appear to be marginal, with inconsistent treatment effects between the two studies and for different endpoints, but the critical question will be what reassurance the company has received from the FDA,” wrote SVB Leerink analyst Geoffrey Porges.

Read more: The Risk to Your Retirement Plans No One Wants to Talk About

Biogen said it had decided to resurrect the drug based on new data that became available after the aducanumab trials were scotched. The company suspended two Phase 3 studies after conducting a “futility analysis” that found that the drug wasn’t having an effect.

New data showed that one of the trials did succeed and one failed, and that patients who received higher doses of the drug in the failed trial showed similar results to patients in the successful trial, Biogen said.

“We believe that these positive results for aducanumab represents a turning point for patients, caregivers, physicians, and scientists in the fight against Alzheimer’s disease,” the company’s chief medical officer, Alfred Sandrock, said on the company’s Tuesday earnings call. “More broadly, we believe this result represented an inflection point in neuroscience drug development and validate our core strategy.”

Yet in a note Tuesday morning, RBC Capital Markets analyst Brian Abrahamshighlighted data in one Biogen slide that showed that in one of the studies, called Engage, patients in the intent-to-treat population who received a high dose of the drug saw a 2% worsening of symptoms compared with the placebo group, based on a key measure. Patients in the same cohort in the other trial saw a 23% improvement.

“Though FDA apparently provided some endorsement for the idea of filing, which could maintain some probability of approvability, we believe the new details suggest the data may be more mixed than initially perceived, and we believe the ENGAGE failure will be a point of controversy as investors debate [aducanumab’s] prospects,” Abrahams wrote.

In a note Tuesday, Mizuho analyst Salim Syed questioned why the trials would have turned out differently from each other. “So the question here is why would two identically designed studies have disparate results,” he wrote. “We really need to understand why. This is why the FDA typically requires two trials, to rule out a fluke.”

Evercore ISI analyst Umer Raffat wrote that, even if the FDA approves the drug, “major commercial acceptance is a whole different debate.”

The reversal from Biogen was major news at the National Alzheimer’s Summit, which started Tuesday in Washington. Speaking at the summit, Jeffrey Cummings of the Cleveland Clinic said that the number of clinical trials for cancer drugs far outstripped those for Alzheimer’s drugs. “That may have changed today,” Cummings said.

Cantor Fitzgerald analyst Alethia Young, in a note out Tuesday, was also positive on the news. “We are currently reviewing our model based on today’s news but think that the big stock move is warranted as investors probably at least move to 50-60% confidence for a potential approval of aducanumab,” she wrote.

The new FDA submission will be based on the updated data set, not a new trial.

—Reshma Kapadia contributed to this article.

Write to Josh Nathan-Kazis at josh.nathan-kazis@barrons.com
description: Shares were up as high as 37% in early trading after the biotech company seemingly erased its signal failure of the year. Some analysts are more cautious.
